conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same time and place, moving in the same direction.
The velocity-time graph shows velocities in terms of v0 and time in terms of t0, with markings up to 6t0.
Particle A has a triangular velocity profile that peaks at 2v0 at t0, and then decreases back to zero by 2t0.
Particle B starts at zero, increases linearly to v0 at 4t0, stays at v0 until 5t0, and then decreases back to zero by 6t0.
Meeting means they are at the same position again at some time.
In a velocity-time graph, the area under the curve represents displacement.

premise: Since they start from rest, their positions can be found by integrating their velocity functions from time 0 to time t.
conclusion: To find when they meet, compare their positions over time and see where their position graphs intersect.

premise: For particle A: From 0 to t0: velocity increases linearly from 0 to 2v0.
For particle A: From t0 to 2t0: velocity decreases linearly from 2v0 to 0.
For particle B: From 0 to 4t0: velocity increases linearly from 0 to v0.
For particle B: From 4t0 to 5t0: velocity remains constant at v0.
For particle B: From 5t0 to 6t0: velocity decreases linearly from v0 to 0.
